accused.name: Jehenne femme Joseph de la Moictresse

confession.devil_appearance: First appeared as great black goat standing on hind legs, then as man in black
confession.seduction_context: She was angry because her husband was a drunkard who beat her and took her property. Devil said he would kill her husband if she would believe in him. Disappeared when she made sign of cross, but soon reappeared as man in black
sabbat_activities: agreed to make people languish and die

harms_alleged.target: daughter of maire Jean Parmentier, wife of late Claude Jean Clerc
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after making soup for her after birth

harms_alleged.target: his daughter, wife of Claude Jean Clerc
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after accused made soup for her post-birth

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jehenne asked to be godmother but was refused due to reputation
His foal would go lick ground outside her house and she would drive it away
Joseph (husband) was angry that Pellerin's son was taking away work Joseph normally did for brother-in-law
testimony.threat_quote: gros Claude warned them that Joseph had been angry and that they should watch out for some misfortune

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Jehenne de la Moictresse and Joseph de la Moictresse

testimony.threat_quote: After son's death Jehenne laughed and said 'qu'il estoit bien employé; qu'il estoit trop prest de saulter et courir par tout'

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Jehenne de la Moictresse and Joseph de la Moictresse

testimony.threat_quote: whenever she met child 'elle disoit par ironie, qu'il n'y coustoit rien, comme sy elle en eut esté marrie que la deposante eut esté sans peine'
que lors qu'elle estoit faschée a quelqu'un elle ne luy en faisoit aucun semblant, et qu'il falloit qu'elle en face de mesme

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jehenne offered to help as midwife but was refused

testimony.threat_quote: When it was said the child would die, Jehenne said it would not

timeline.subject: Jehenne and Joseph de la Moictresse
timeline.details: After St Martin 1619, they were accused by Denis Louis and fled Nutting

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Statement from maire, sergent, and clerc juré at Nutting about her residence and flight

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Initial interrogation about background and flight

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for evidence to be taken against her

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Four witnesses heard (Barbeline, Jean Parmentier, Annon and Remys Masson)

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves showing instruments and thumbscrews only

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews on hands and feet but confessed nothing

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for more witnesses to be heard

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire only

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Racked and confessed to witchcraft, sabbat attendance, and maleficia

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence, subject to final repetition

timeline.subject: Jehenne de la Moictresse
timeline.details: Formal sentence from court at Blamont

torture.restrictions: First session: thumbscrews only. Second session: question ordinaire only (not extraordinaire)

accomplices_named.name: Denys Louys (Denis Louis)
accomplices_named.context: Attended sabbat with her, gave her powder to make people languish and die

accomplices_named.name: Jennon femme Gerardin Marchal
accomplices_named.context: Attended sabbat near Autrepierre with her, dancing back to back. Also in prison at same time and confronted with accused

accomplices_named.name: la grande Babillon
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat near Nutting in first year

accomplices_named.name: la Pancée (or le Pancré)
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat near Nutting in first year

accomplices_named.name: Jean Didier
accomplices_named.context: Was musician at sabbat near Autrepierre, using large piece of wood. Seen at multiple sabbats

accomplices_named.name: Gerardin Marchal's wife
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat near Autrepierre with her husband

accomplices_named.name: Joseph de la Moictresse (her husband)
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat near Autrepierre. She said he asked her for powder to harm Jean Pellerin's son, sprinkled it on his path causing his death. She thought from this time he was a witch

prior_accusations.context: Accused Jehenne and her husband after St Martin 1619, maintained charges up to his execution, causing them to flee

notable_quotes.speaker: Jehenne de la Moictresse
notable_quotes.context: Her response to Jean Parmentier's testimony during confrontations

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbe femme Jean Pellerin
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit bien employé; qu'il estoit trop prest de saulter et courir par tout
notable_quotes.english: that he deserved it; that he was too ready to jump and run everywhere
notable_quotes.context: What Jehenne allegedly said laughing after death of Pellerin's son

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudatte femme Anthoine du Prey
notable_quotes.french: elle disoit par ironie, qu'il n'y coustoit rien, comme sy elle en eut esté marrie que la deposante eut esté sans peine
notable_quotes.english: she said ironically that it cost nothing, as if she was sorry that the witness was without trouble
notable_quotes.context: What Jehenne allegedly said when meeting the sick child

notable_quotes.speaker: Chrestienne femme Nicolas Macon
notable_quotes.french: que lors qu'elle estoit faschée a quelqu'un elle ne luy en faisoit aucun semblant, et qu'il falloit qu'elle en face de mesme
notable_quotes.english: that when she was angry with someone she did not show it at all, and that one must do the same
notable_quotes.context: Advice Jehenne allegedly gave to her former servant about hiding anger

notable_quotes.speaker: Jehenne de la Moictresse
notable_quotes.french: que sy elle eut esté riche que l'on ne l'eut accusé mais que l'on l'avoit ravaudé pour ce qu'elle estoit pauvre
notable_quotes.english: that if she had been rich they would not have accused her, but they had harassed her because she was poor
notable_quotes.context: Her comment about economic motivations behind accusations, reported by Chrestienne

relationships.evidence_text: Jehenne femme Joseph de la Moictresse
her mother had been executed as witch
her aunt at Autrepierre had been executed as witch
her aunt Hellenix at Blamont had been executed as witch
another aunt at Migneville had been executed as witch
Barbeline veuve Demenge Henriot

relationships.person2: wife of late Claude Jean Clerc
relationships.evidence_text: daughter of maire Jean Parmentier, wife of late Claude Jean Clerc

relationships.person2: wife of late Claude Jean Clerc

Annon femme Remys Masson and Remys Masson
Mongeate femme du precedent (Jacques Gerard)
Jehenne veuve Louy Denys
his son died suddenly
Barbe femme du precedent (Jean Pellerin)

her sister, the wife of Jean le Fort

economic_context.details: Jehenne said she was seduced by devil when angry because husband was drunkard who beat her and took her property. Economic tensions over work - Joseph was angry that Pellerin's son was taking work he normally did. Jehenne explicitly stated 'if she had been rich they would not have accused her, but they harassed her because she was poor'. Husband's relatives sold their goods to pay a debt after they fled. Evidence of poverty driving accusations.

harms_catalog.victim_name: daughter of Jean Parmentier, wife of Claude Jean Clerc
harms_catalog.harm_description: Went all blue and died in 3 days after childbirth
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness wanted to prevent Jehenne from making soup for woman after birth due to reputation, but she insisted
Jehenne asked to be godmother but was refused because of her reputation
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft after being refused godmother role

harms_catalog.harm_description: Found dead between other horses which were unscathed during storm
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Foal annoyed her by going to lick ground outside her house, she often drove it away
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Claimed to have seen lightning strike barn but no damage to building. Smell of sulphur. Under torture confessed to using powder

harms_catalog.victim_name: wife of master Ms Caba at Benamesnil
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: In hope that master would marry her instead

harms_catalog.attributed_to: Jehenne and Joseph de la Moictresse
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Joseph was angry that young man was taking away work he normally did for his brother-in-law
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 6 months after warning from gros Claude
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Under torture, Jehenne said husband asked her for powder and sprinkled it on the young man's path

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Claudatte femme Anthoine du Prey
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Under torture confessed to using powder. Later said child died of smallpox

harms_catalog.victim_name: first child of Chrestienne femme Nicolas Macon
harms_catalog.harm_description: Would not suckle and died in 5 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness tried to keep her away from baby after birth; suggestion that as hostess she did not want baby around

harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost her milk for some days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jehenne offered to help as midwife but witness refused, preferring to send to Hesse
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Great mass of hair found under pillow

harms_catalog.victim_name: nephew, son of Jean le Fort

material_culture.context: Jehenne insisted on making soup for woman after childbirth despite objections
Devil gave her black powder to kill husband and to cause harms; shared powder at sabbat
Devil gave her money which turned out to be leaves
Put powder on bread to kill nephew
Found under pillow of woman in childbed, suspected to cause loss of milk
Put on new shoes when fleeing hurriedly
Husband had taken their linen out of house by night before fleeing
Only items left in house when they fled
Nephew took her cherries, precipitating his death
Used as musical instrument by Jean Didier at sabbat
Husband traded in grain during their time in Chalpach

spatial_references.context: Primary location where accused lived for 10 years after marriage and where accusations began
Native village of accused; location of some witnesses and sabbat locations
Where accused and husband lived for a year after fleeing, in separate houses
Near Nutting; spent 3 weeks there spinning while husband traded in grain from Strasbourg
Location of court that issued final judgment; also location of aunt Hellenix who was executed as witch
Location of another aunt who was executed as witch
Pilgrimage site where Jehenne was sent with 2 servants
Where Jehenne and witness 8 were both in service 18-20 years earlier
Where officials went on business; husband saw them there and they fled
Where witness sent for midwife rather than using Jehenne
Source of grain husband traded in
Sabbat location attended 4 times in first year

weather_events: storm during which Jacques Gerard's foal died
hail - confessed to making at sabbat
economic_hardship_indicators: husband was drunkard who took her property
work competition between Joseph and others
accused stated they harassed her because she was poor

change_de_nancy.modification_details: First request for ordinaire et extraordinaire approved as thumbscrews only (18 May 1621). Second request for ordinaire et extraordinaire approved as ordinaire only (7 June 1621). Death sentence approved subject to final repetition of confessions (11 June 1621).

hearsay_chains.content: Said to have killed wife of master Ms Caba at Benamesnil
What Jehenne allegedly said ironically about her sick child

emotional_state_notes: made one or two suggestions of theft against witnesses but no serious reproaches

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Denied having any memory of making soup, claimed sick woman had 2 or 3 midwives around her
Denied remark about illness and called him 'un faussaire' (liar)
Denied saying she had seen lightning strike barn
Said child had died of smallpox
Claimed to know nothing of Thiery Faltin being on point of becoming partie formelle against her

third_parties.name: Denis Louis (Louy Denys)
third_parties.context: Accused Jehenne and her husband after St Martin 1619, maintained charges up to his execution. At his execution he allegedly discharged them. Later named as sabbat accomplice who gave her powder

third_parties.name: gros Claude
third_parties.context: Warned Jean Pellerin that Joseph had been angry about losing work and to watch out for misfortune

third_parties.name: Ms Caba
third_parties.context: Master at Benamesnil whose wife Jehenne allegedly killed 18-20 years earlier

third_parties.name: wife of Jean le Fort
third_parties.context: Arrived and warned Jehenne she was about to be arrested, prompting immediate flight

third_parties.name: Jean le Fort
third_parties.context: His son (accused's nephew) was killed by accused because he took her cherries

third_parties.name: Jean Didier
third_parties.context: Musician at sabbat near Autrepierre, using large piece of wood. Seen at multiple sabbats

third_parties.name: Gerardin Marchal
third_parties.context: His wife was being held in prison with Jehenne and confronted her. Seen at sabbat

third_parties.name: Claude Jean Clerc
third_parties.context: Late husband of Jean Parmentier's daughter who died after childbirth

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with extensive witness testimony (15 witnesses), two torture sessions, full confession under torture, and named accomplices. Strong evidence of economic motivations behind accusations. Notable for accused's explicit statement about poverty driving accusations. Family history of witch executions (mother and three aunts). Fled before arrest but was captured. Husband also implicated. Trial shows pattern of accusations following social slights and economic competition.
